questions.text: Among the anatomical structures involved in respiration, which of the following are included in the gas exchange area during respiration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Here in this question out of the options, only the Alveolar sacs come under the Respiratory/Alveolar airway, which actually take part in the gas exchange. According to the Wiebel model there are 23 generations in the respiratory tree. These are divided into two zones
    • Conducting airway- From Trachea to the Terminal Bronchiole -First 16 generations
    • Respiratory/Exchange /Alveolar airways- From Respiratory bronchiole to alveoli- last 7 Generations
  • The conducting zone does not take part in gas exchange. This space is also called anatomical dead space..

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presents with recurrent lower respiratory tract infections, chronic sinusitis, and a history of bronchiectasis. On further evaluation, he is also found to have infertility. High-speed video microscopy and electron microscopy of nasal epithelium reveal immotile cilia with absent dynein arms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Here the 43-year-old patient presents with classic clinical features and investigation findings that strongly indicate Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD).
  • PCD is a congenital disorder characterized by structural and/or functional abnormalities of motile cilia, leading to impaired mucociliary clearance and associated complications.
  • These defects impair mucociliary clearance in the respiratory tract and can also affect sperm motility in males leading to infertility, chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and recurrent respiratory infections.
  • Approximately 50% of cases have situs inversus, known as Kartagener syndrome (a subtype of PCD).

Explanation of other options:

  • Cystic fibrosis(option A): It is a genetic disorder caused by mutation in the CFTR gene which codes for chloride channels resulting in thick, sticky mucus in multiple organs and exocrine gland dysfunction.
  • Usually presents in childhood, with pancreatic insufficiency, elevated sweat chloride, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies.
  • COPD(Option B): It is an acquired disease caused by chronic smoking, no infertility or ciliary defects.
  • ABPA(Option D): Allergic reaction in asthma with infection; no structural ciliary dysfunction.

Key takeaway:

  • Ciliary dysfunction can occur in all of these -
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Chronic smoking
    • Primary ciliary dyskinesia

questions.text: Which of the following is not primarily involved in the defence mechanism of the respiratory tract?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • There are two types of Alveolar cells:
    • Type 1 pneumocytes are flat, thin cells which cover almost 95% of the Alveolar surface and are functioning for the Alveolar air and capillary blood. They are not primarily involved in the defence mechanisms.
    • Type 2 pneumocytes are Granular pneumocytes. They are thicker and contain numerous lamellar inclusion bodies and Secrete surfactant.
  • The airway epithelium and it is pseudostratified epithelium containing goblet cells.These cells secrete mucus. Any microorganism entering in the tract sticks to the secretion and is thrown out via the synchronised retrograde movement of ciliary towards the nasopharynx(Metachronism).
  • Pulmonary alveolar macrophages are types of tissue macrophages present in the alveoli.They engulf any foreign bacteria which enters in the respiratory tract via mechanism of phagocytosis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with recurrent pulmonary infections, failure to thrive, and bulky foul-smelling stools. Sweat chloride levels are elevated. Genetic analysis reveals a mutation on chromosome 7 affecting an epithelial ion transport protein. Which of the following combinations most likely explains the underlying pathophysiology in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario the child's symptoms of recurrent respiratory infections, steatorrhea (bulky foul-smelling stools), and failure to thrive, along with elevated sweat chloride are all classical for Cystic Fibrosis (CF). It is an autosomal recessive disease.
  • CF is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) on chromosome 7 and the most common mutation is of ΔF508 mutation.
  • The other options G551D,R117H,N1303K are all mutations of CFTR gene but less common.(Option A,Option B and Option D ruled out)
  • This gene encodes a cAMP-regulated ATP-gated chloride channel located on epithelial cells of the lungs, pancreas, intestine, and sweat glands.
  • Clinical features in cystic fibrosis:
    • Respiratory System:
      • Chronic cough, recurrent pulmonary infections, bronchiectasis, nasal polyps, clubbing
    • Gastrointestinal:
      • Meconium ileus (in neonates), pancreatic insufficiency, malabsorption, steatorrhea
    • Hepatobiliary system:
      • Biliary cirrhosis, fatty liver
    • Reproductive system:
      • Male infertility (CBAVD), delayed puberty
    • Other Salty sweat, failure to thrive
  • Treatment options include:
    • Chest physiotherapy, mucolytics, inhaled bronchodilators,Antibiotics,Pancreatic enzyme replacement, fat-soluble vitamins (ADEK), CFTR Modulators Ivacaftor (G551D), Lumacaftor/Tezacaftor (ΔF508) and in advanced cases Lung transplantation is the only option.

Key takeaway:

  • CF is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) on chromosome 7 and the most common mutation is of ΔF508 mutation and treated with CFTR modulators like ivacaftor.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He complains of chest pain and difficulty in breathing. On examination, there is tenderness over the lower ribs and decreased breath sounds on the affected side. His tidal volume is significantly reduced. Which of the following muscles is most likely injured and responsible for the impaired ventilation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario the patient met with an accident and sustained injury to the lower thorax region. The lower rib tenderness suggests injury at the origin of Diaphragm and the decreased breath sounds, decreased tidal volume are due compromised diaphragmatic movement resulting in impaired ventilation.
  • Diaphragm and external intercostal muscles are responsible for normal inspiration. Nearly 70% of tidal inspiration is due to diaphragm and is called the principle muscle of inspiration(Option A ruled out).
  • Scaleni, sternocleidomastoid, alae nasi, serratus anterior are accessory muscles of inspiration.(Option D ruled out)
  • Abdominal recti and Internal intercostal muscles are accessory expiratory muscles. Normal tidal expiration is a passive process.(Option B ruled out)
  • The diaphragm is made up of three parts:
    • The costal fibres are muscle fibers that are attached to the ribs around the bottom of the thoracic cage.
    • The crural fibers attached to the ligaments along the vertebrae.
    • The central tendon, into which the costal and the crural fibers insert.
  • The costal and crural portions are innervated by different parts of the phrenic nerve and can contract separately.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • Nearly 70% of tidal inspiration is due to diaphragm. External intercostal muscles also help in inspiration but diaphragm has 70% contribution in it.

questions.text: During inspiration, which of the following pressures reaches the most negative (lowest) value?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pleural pressure is the pressure of the fluid in the thin space between the lung pleura and chest wall pleura. Normally negative even at rest (around -5 cm H2O).During inspiration, it becomes more negative (e.g., -7 to -8 cm H2O) as the chest wall expands and pulls the lungs outward.
  • It is the most negative (least) pressure in the respiratory cycle.

Explanation of other options:

  • Alveolar Pressure (Intrapulmonary Pressure)(Option B): At rest it is equal to atmospheric pressure(0mmhg of water) and during inspiration it drops slightly to around -1 cm H2O to allow air inflow.
  • Transpulmonary Pressure (P(tp) = P(alv) - P(pl))(Option C): Always positive (because alveolar pressure > pleural pressure).
  • During inspiration: it increases as pleural pressure drops.This helps keep lungs expanded.
  • Partial Pressure of CO2 in Alveoli (PACO2)(Option D): Normally ~40 mm Hg at rest.Slightly decreases during inspiration due to fresh air entry, but remains positive and nowhere near the low (negative) pleural pressures.

Key takeaway:

  • During normal inspiration, expansion of the chest cage pulls outward on the lungs with greater force and creates more negative pressure to an average of about -7.5 cm H2O in pleura which is lowest among all.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman underwent abdominal surgery under general anesthesia. Postoperatively, she developed coughing, breathlessness, and fever. A Chest X-ray was taken on POD-2 which revealed patchy infiltrates in the right lower lobe suggestive of aspiration pneumonia. Review of intraoperative events revealed delayed recovery of protective airway reflexes.
Which of the following is the most likely physiological mechanism responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In this clinical scenario the patient has acquired Aspiration pneumonia post-anesthesia, it is typically due to failure of glottic closure,impaired contraction of the adductor muscles of the larynx, which protect the lower airway.Opening and closure of the vocal folds are important in inspiration and expiration.
  • The abductor muscles contract which pulls the vocal folds apart to open the glottis for the entry of air into the lungs during inspiration.(Option A ruled out)
  • The adductor muscles of the larynx when contracted closes the glottis and does not allow the air to enter into the lungs. It occurs during swallowing or gagging. It prevents the entry of food into the lungs.
  • In an anesthetized patient the adductor muscles of the larynx do not contract completely in some cases, so some fluid, food or vomitus may be aspirated into the lungs causing the inflammatory changes into the lungs. It causes aspiration pneumonia.
  • Injury to phrenic nerve would cause diaphragmatic paralysis and hypoventilation.(Option B)

Key Takeaways:

The adductor muscles of the larynx when contracted closes the glottis and does not allow the air to enter into the lungs. It occurs during swallowing or gagging. It prevents the entry of food into the lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following thoracic cage dimensions is primarily increased by the "pump handle" movement during inspiration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The external intercostal muscles run obliquely downward and forward from rib to rib. The ribs act as pivots and are hinged at the back. When these muscles contract they elevate the ribs.
  • Elevation of ribs increase the anteroposterior diameter by pump handle movement and transverse diameter by bucket handle movement.
  • Normal tidal inspiration is an active process and expiration a passive one.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • The pump handle movement involves the upper ribs (1st to 6th), where the ribs and sternum move upward and forward, increasing the anteroposterior diameter of the thorax. This motion resembles the lifting of a pump handle.
  • The bucket handle movement involves the lower ribs (7th to 10th), where the ribs move upward and outward, increasing the transverse diameter of the thoracic cavity. This motion is similar to lifting the handle of a bucket.
